item.title: Qld uni activist will appeal suspension
item.description: A student activist highly critical of the University of Queensland's ties to Beijing will appeal his two-year suspension, claiming the decision is politically motivated.

item.title: Charges laid against cargo ship master
item.description: The Australian Marine Safety Authority has laid charges against the master of the APL England, for offences relating to pollution and damage of the marine environment as a result of poor cargo loading.

item.title: Hungary honours 2019 Danube boat victims
item.description: Commemorations have begun in Hungary for the first anniversary of the Danube River accident in which more than two dozen South Korean tourists died after their tour boat collided with a river cruise ship.

item.title: India’s virus death toll passes China
item.description: India has reported a jump of 7466 coronavirus cases over the past 24 hours, its biggest one-day surge, as the country relaxes lockdown measures.

item.title: Hong Kong protest over China security law
item.description: Dozens of people have joined a protest in a mall in Hong Kong after the vote by China's parliament to approve legislation which might severely restrict opposition political activity and civic activity in the Asian financial centre.

item.title: Ex-nurse Joan’s 102 laps in NHS fundraiser
item.description: A 101-year-old retired English nurse has raised thousands of pounds for the NHS as she aims to walk 102 laps of her local park before she turns 102.

item.title: Ohio Floyd death protest turns violent
item.description: An initially peaceful demonstration by protesters, angry over the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis police custody, has turned violent in Columbus, leaving smashed shop windows along downtown streets around the statehouse.

item.title: Indonesia’s 24 new coronavirus deaths
item.description: Indonesia has reported on Friday 678 new coronavirus infections, taking the total number of cases in the southeast Asian country to 25,216.

item.title: US Uighur bill an interfering smear: China
item.description: China Foreign Ministry says the US bill proposing to sanction its officials over treatment of the Uighur minority blatantly smears Beijing's anti-terrorism efforts and severely interferes in the country's internal affairs.

item.title: WA restrictions ease, ship cases spike
item.description: Western Australia will be the first state to abandon the nationwide four square metre rule as it lifts a raft of COVID-19 restrictions, raising the limit on gatherings to 100 people and allowing many businesses to reopen.
